fields.description:
You spent the last four years being a college kid. And that's wonderful. But a lot can happen in four years, and Facebook never forgets. You partied. You befriended some questionable characters. Heck, you just lived your life and did your thing - and now, you've got the posts and pics to show it.

But do you have the time and energy and robotic perfection to hunt down all those little details? No! And even if you just said, "Yes!", you're wrong. These things creep into the corners of the internet and lie in wait for the day you decide to BECOME A PROFESSIONAL.

That's right, GROW UP. But avoid those growing pains and maintain a fresh face - easily - with SimpleWash. Wash away all those dirty little jokes and those late night snapshots, those forgotten "likes." Keep track of all the dirt and grime that attaches to your social self and make you STAY FRESH.
fields.title: SimpleWash

fields.description:
A tool for collective thinking.  Remesh allows a group of people (a mesh) to respond as a single unit to questions or events, or simply to speak as one.  The collective response is that which represents the collective thinking of the group.  This is achieved through the use of an evolving set of responses, where evolutionary outcomes are based on mesh user feedback, and languages models are used to create new responses species based on currently dominating responses.  

The goal of this project is to allow large groups of people,from local communities to continents to be able to speak as one, so that their voices may be heard directly.

Team Members: Andrew Konya, Alisha Konya, Konstantin Khitrin, Eli Gundry
fields.title: Remesh

fields.description: On March 8th to the 10th hacKSU will be hosting a hackathon! 37 hours hacking away at those wild and wooly applications you've been dreaming up. With a bunch of other hackers - hacking a really, really good time. With delicious food. And cool prizes. Sign up on our hacker league page and check out all the details on our page below!
fields.title: Kent Hack Enough

fields.description:
LaunchPad's 2nd student networking. 

Free food and refreshments!

Welcome student entrepreneurs, programmers, marketers, graphic designers, accountants, freelancers, and any others interested or feeling creative.

Build connections, ideas or business partners.
fields.title: Student Networking

fields.description: This week's meeting we are going to take a look some awesome javascript libraries on the web. Go ahead and check them out. We are sure that you will want to start using them right away!
fields.title: Awesome JavaScript Libraries

fields.description:
This week coming up we will be giving a Ruby on Rails presentation! Ruby on Rails is a great web framework that has proved to be very reliable and super scalable over the years. It is one of the most used web frameworks in Computer Science. 

In order to get started for next week you young hackers must be sure to come prepared and ready to learn for Tuesday. This involves getting your Rails environment set up correctly. Below is the single best tool to installing Rails on your machine. It will include all the packages necessary and should get you up in running in no time.

If you have any problems please just send us an email and we will work it out. We should also be at the meeting an hour early in case you need some hands on expertise. ;)
fields.title: Introduction to Ruby and Rails

fields.description: This Tuesday on the 3rd floor of the Math and Computer Science building, we are going to get into some really cool stuff! We will be offering 3 different topics AT THE SAME TIME. Why? Cause they’re platform dependent! For Windows folks, we will be having a session on C# (taught by CS department’s very own Eric Soros!), and for Mac folks, we will be having a session on AppleScript. For Linux folks, we can do some good old Python. You can do amazing things with these languages! Come ready for some fun and food!
fields.title: Learning C#, AppleScript, and Python

fields.description: This week (Tuesday at 7pm in the MSB Library) we thought we should get back to web development and talk about preprocessing languages that are available. We will cover Sass for CSS and CoffeeScript for Javascript both of which are detailed below. These are some key languages to learn for the web development space and will make you an even better coder! What’s even better is that you can start using these for your Rails projects that we started last week. As always come hungry and lets have a good time learning some wicked cool languages. Sass (Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets) is an extension of CSS3, adding nested rules, variables, mixins, selector inheritance, and more. It's translated to well-formatted, standard CSS using the command line tool or a web-framework plugin. CoffeeScript is a little language that compiles into JavaScript. Underneath that awkward Java-esque patina, JavaScript has always had a gorgeous heart. CoffeeScript is an attempt to expose the good parts of JavaScript in a simple way.
fields.title: Hack Sass while you drink some CoffeeScript!

fields.description: We will be splitting up into two sections: the first section will be learning to develop their very own website and the second will be focusing on some sweet HTML5 APIs. All workshop material can be found on our GitHub page by following the links below. Let's have a great start to the year!
fields.title: Web workshop

fields.description: A student at Kent State University, Camden Fullmer is currently studying Computer Science and Applied Mathematics. He is also interning at Kent Displays Inc. as the head of mobile applications development. Design is always on his mind and nothing is safe from his critiquing. At the same time, he likes to keep it real with very technical backend work.
fields.name: Camden Fullmer

fields.description: Daniel was born and raised in Johannesburg, South Africa. Currently studying Computer Science and Applied Mathematics at Kent State University. Interned at Google, New York in May and will be returning in May 2013 to do another internship. Enjoy mobile and web development!
fields.name: Daniel Gur

fields.description: David is currently pursuing degrees in Computer Science and Electronic Media Production at Kent State University and is researching for his Honors Thesis, "Developing an Easily Accessible Web Framework." He is an intern at Kent Displays Inc. as the Macintosh programming lead. Text mining and API development are his greatest interests, stemming from a life-long love of all things linguistic.
fields.name: David "Dàwèi" Steinberg
